canard.sentence_1: The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.

diminutive.sentence_2: When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.
diminutive.sentence_1: He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: "Bill" instead of "John William."

promulgate.sentence_1: The President wanted to promulgate the success of the treaty negotiations, but he had to wait until Congress formally approved the agreement.

eponym.sentence_1: Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.
eponym.meaning_1: noun: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is named

splenetic.sentence_1: Ever since the car accident, Frank has been unable to walk without a cane, and so he has become splenetic and unpleasant to be around.

lachrymose.sentence_1: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

demonstrative.sentence_1: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.
demonstrative.meaning_1: adjective: given to or marked by the open expression of emotion

sardonic.sentence_1: A stand-up comedian walks a fine line when making jokes about members of the audience; such fun and joking can quickly become sardonic and cutting.
sardonic.meaning_1: adjective: disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking

oblique.sentence_1: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.
oblique.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

concomitant.sentence_1: Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.
concomitant.meaning_1: adjective: describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in connection with another

despot.sentence_1: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.
despot.meaning_1: noun: a cruel and oppressive dictator

ebullient.sentence_1: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

cataclysm.sentence_1: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.
cataclysm.meaning_1: noun: an event resulting in great loss and misfortune

bastardization.sentence_1: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.
bastardization.meaning_1: noun: an act that debases or corrupts

row.sentence_1: The Prime Minister looked very foolish after his row with the foreign dignitary was caught on video and posted on youtube.
row.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

enamored.sentence_1: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.
enamored.meaning_1: adjective: strongly attracted to or in love with.

exiguity.sentence_1: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.
exiguity.meaning_1: noun: the quality of being meager

countermand.sentence_1: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.
countermand.meaning_1: verb: a contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command

loath.sentence_1: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.
loath.meaning_1: adjective: unwilling to do something contrary to your custom (usually followed by 'to')

surfeit.sentence_1: There was no such thing as a surfeit of shopping for Nancy--she could stay at the outlet stores from opening to closing time.
surfeit.meaning_1: noun: an excessive amount of something

exorbitant.sentence_1: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.
exorbitant.meaning_1: adjective: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

adjudicate.sentence_1: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.
adjudicate.meaning_1: verb: to serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion

raillery.sentence_1: The new recruit was not bothered by the raillery, finding most of it light-hearted and good-natured.

capitulate.sentence_1: Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.
capitulate.meaning_1: verb: to surrender (usually under agreed conditions)

infelicitous.sentence_1: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

trenchant.sentence_1: Jill presented a rather superficial treatment of sales in Asia, but her trenchant analysis of sales in Europe inspired a number of insights into how to proceed in that market.
trenchant.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by or full of force and vigor; having keenness and forcefulness and penetration in thought, expression, or intellect

panacea.sentence_1: While the company credit card has made most large purchases easier, it is no panacea: some smaller basic transactions still must be conducted in cash.
panacea.meaning_1: noun: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; a universal solution

halcyon.sentence_1: The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.
halcyon.meaning_1: adjective: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and prosperity

dissemble.sentence_1: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.
dissemble.meaning_1: verb: conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit

simulacrum.sentence_2: The early days of computer graphics made real people into a simulacrum that now seems comical.
simulacrum.sentence_1: The Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center showcases a simulacrum of all the present and approved buildings in the city of Shanghai.
simulacrum.meaning_1: noun: a representation of a person (especially in the form of sculpture)

dissolution.sentence_1: Many Roman emperors were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.
dissolution.meaning_1: noun: a living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure

hoodwink.sentence_1: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.
hoodwink.meaning_1: verb: to deceive or trick someone

misattribute.sentence_1: I made a mistake; I misattributed "Crime and Punishment" to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.
misattribute.meaning_1: verb: To erroneously attribute; to falsely ascribe; used especially of authorship.

chauvinism.sentence_1: Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do.
chauvinism.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
chauvinism.meaning_1: noun: fanatical patriotism; belief that one's group/cause is superior to all other groups/causes

flag.sentence_1: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.
flag.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
flag.meaning_1: verb: droop, sink, or settle from or as if from pressure or loss of tautness; become less intense

officious.sentence_1: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.
officious.meaning_1: adjective: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner

modicum.sentence_1: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.
modicum.meaning_1: noun: a small or moderate or token amount

extrapolate.sentence_1: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.
extrapolate.meaning_1: verb: draw from specific cases for more general cases

graft.sentence_1: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.
graft.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

verisimilitude.sentence_1: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

obtain.sentence_1: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.
obtain.meaning_1: verb: be valid, applicable, or true

veritable.sentence_1: Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

ineluctable.sentence_1: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.
ineluctable.meaning_1: adjective: impossible to avoid or evade:

abrogate.sentence_1: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.
abrogate.meaning_1: verb: revoke or relinquish formally; do away with

estimable.sentence_1: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.
estimable.meaning_1: adjective: deserving of esteem and respect

evanescent.sentence_1: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time—an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.
evanescent.meaning_1: adjective: tending to vanish like vapor

bereft.sentence_2: "You are not bereft if you haven't played on your Xbox in the past week," his mother said.
bereft.sentence_1: After 64 years of marriage, William was bereft after the death of his wife.
bereft.meaning_1: adjective: unhappy in love; suffering from unrequited love
bereft.meaning_2: adjective: sorrowful through loss or deprivation

palaver.sentence_1: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.
palaver.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
palaver.meaning_1: verb: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly

dissipate.sentence_2: Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.
dissipate.sentence_1: The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico.
dissipate.meaning_1: verb: squander or spend money frivolously

pillory.sentence_1: After the candidate confessed, the press of the opposing party took the opportunity to pillory him, printing editorials with the most blatantly exaggerated accusations.
pillory.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pillory.meaning_1: verb: ridicule or expose to public scorn
